thread.title: 'Back to the Future' on Oct. 21, 2015: What the movie got right, wrong and how O.C.'s celebrating
thread.title_full: 'Back to the Future' on Oct. 21, 2015: What the movie got right, wrong and how O.C.'s celebrating - Press Enterprise

author: PETER LARSEN
title: 'Back to the Future' on Oct. 21, 2015: What the movie got right, wrong and how O.C.'s celebrating
text:
By PETER LARSEN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 20, 2015 Updated: Oct. 21, 2015 10:57 a.m. Great Scott! It’s here!
Oct. 21, 2015: The date on which Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly and Christopher Lloyd as Doc Brown landed after time traveling in the second installment of the “Back to the Future” film trilogy.
Or you can look at it as the date that filmmakers pondered when they tried to imagine what the world of the semi-distant future – our time – would be like.
Here, let’s see how they did.
Look up. See any flying cars?
OK, that one didn’t quite pan out.
But pick up your phone and talk to a friend on FaceTime or Skype. Video calls! Nailed it!
And that’s not all. Garbage-fueled cars? Glasses that double as computers? The Cubs playing meaningful baseball in October? The movie made more than a few lucky/clever guesses.
So, today, as theaters prep to show the “Back” trilogy, as fans gather in Los Angeles to start a five-day celebration called “We’re Going Back” – and anybody lucky enough to own a DeLorean is likely to get mobbed – we went to sort out “Back” facts from fiction.
And, along the way, we’ll clue you in to a few ways to celebrate the big day.
THEN AND NOW
Then and now: See what 'Back to the Future' locations look like 30 years after the movie
HOVERBOARDS
When Fox as Marty McFly arrives in Hill Valley on Oct. 21, 2015, he is totally stoked to find that skateboards have shed their wheels and become hoverboards.
Our ruling here is fiction, though in recent years a few companies have demonstrated prototypes of boards that “hover” using magnetic levitation. But these work only over metallic surfaces, so they’re more gimmick than reality.
